element_texts.text: Completed
Bound Cover of diary no writing
Completed

July 1, 1853 - Du Quoin, Illinois Went to ride today - found some specimens of new flowers and analyzed them with Isaac in the evening. Our dear little Mayo just one month old today- weighs nearly ten pounds 
July 2 - Mitchell & Crosby back today. Misses Paine & Reynolds gone probably not to return to board here. I took baby out to ride today in the morning and picked some berries - Hackberries & dew berries in abundance now & chiggers too. little miserable red rascals about as large as the point of a pin. could not be seen possibly but for this color. I don't believe they have a friend in the wide world.They certainly do not show themselves friendly. The bite is a sting and makes a large sore sometimes. Shows how much little people can accomplish sometimes.
Completed

July 3 -  Sabbath - and I went to church in A.M. heard Rev. Wiley - very good sermon - I ought to be better for it - Text "ye are bought with a price" &c. Baby slept all the while I was gone - (Isaac reached Dun. one year agow)
July 4 - Mr. Shepherd an oration at ten & Isaac read Dec. of Ind. after, and then came home in desparation - weary of the hard seats & stale & uninteresting discoursings - Crosby here & they at the office drank lemonade in honor of the day - Crosby and lady with four or five more pairs marched with a cold water banner to a neighbors dwelling where they had arranged to have a dinner provided Mr Keyes gave me a delightful ride after tea - Isaac went to Mount St. to meet the mail.
Completed

July 5 - Beautiful day - One year of happy wedded life is gone One year since I left my parents dwellings then came for a love untried & new  Thank God for what this year has proved. I am blessed & most truly blessed - Who has so much for which to offer praise. While I thank Heaven for my treasures-my husband and our child, may aid from thence be given me to discharge my duties to them, and to us both, that we may together train the the little ones for a useful life, unclear to us, and for a heavenly home. There is strength in One, and His own promise is "Ask and it shall be given"-" Tis a fond yet a fearful thing to rule? oer the opening mind" who must bear the impress it receives forever
Completed

July 6 - Mr & Mrs Willis arrived last Eve - are to board here. She an old friend of "Yankee Settlement" - six years ago and here we meet again  Fortunes wheel has turned us up together, when we thought not of it.  Isaac gone to Big Muddy - I almost ha??ed? "The Old folks at home" - played it till tired - Finished the second pair of pants for Isaac - cut & made them - a novel occupation for me - Baby slept almost all day - Dear little charge - what a work for us. I must look away from self and act in the living present - heart within and God over head" -  Isaac home about ten  I had just at dark thrown myself with my clothes on and baby on my arm onto the bed and there we were when he came fast asleep
Completed

July 7 - Bought twelve quarts of blackberries to make jelly - Made pant in P.M - I went to ride at night with Isaac to the mill - Saw flowers all along the way - most showy the Trumpet Creeper - heard the Katydids in Evening giving a concert That same little whistling bird is here that you heard in Maine  Specimens of all the varieties of bird & insect abounding here would form a large and attractive collection for a Naturalist - Talked with Mrs Nellis in Eve. about Lockport people -
Completed

July 8  Friday

Isaac away through the day on the line  Mrs. Nellis taken violently sick in the night - sent for Dr. W. Belten? this morn. Mrs Keyes Abby and I sat with her today by turn Thought I should sew consi?..? just to?? of the skant? of adress? "only this and nothing more" - and not a stitch - Keeping flies off the sick lady - watching her little boy and my own took all the time - waited a long while for my usual glass of milk at night, but the cows chose not come - too warm to eat by sunlight she stoped? to browse by the light of the moon - as they do occasionally when the day is unusually warm - The prairie lands about give up? a??re? to flocks without number? - The cows here are simply
Completed

turned into the road and they find for themselves the open prairies just out of the village over which they wander at will during the day and in the cool of Evening come stalking leisurely home again - One big pasture for the whole community of four footed beasts -
July 9 Saturday
Isaac at home - baby not sleeping as much as usual quite  Sometimes his nappings last a whole half day - sometimes they are only about an inch long -  Letters from Lucy & Mother M - dear good people - such friends are worth words of gold & silver -  tongues cannot tell nor human mind conceive this worth who gave them - May he spare them long years to come and give them joy in life & death
Completed

Sabbath - July 10

Did not go to church - wrote a letter to my mother -

Monday - 11

 Isaac at home - I carried pitcher of jelly to Mrs Keyes  - talked with her about my health - she said I must take wine every day "for mi? often infirmities" - She is a good mother  Went to ride with her after tea - Cool & pleasant  - pure white clouds all about in magnificent piles -  Isaac taught me the mystery of the Safe tonight -  & I might get the? Rowley's money for him   

Tuesday - 12

 Isaac went away early this morning for the week  finished letter home and wrote little to brother M? - Went to the store with Mrs Nells after supper  rode with Mrs Keyes - got chiggers & Hackberries. Rec'd Putnam's Monthly
Completed

Wednesday, 13 July 
Washed & dressed baby & went to sleep in his carriage. Baby laughed loud when I sing.  Had tomatoes & green corn today & beets. Mr Rowley came at night. I began letters to Anna. Mr Sheppard came & wanted me to play, Baby six weeks old - 11 lbs 1 oz in? weight
Thursday 14 July Finished letter to Anna. Ruth McClum? called.
Friday 15 July 
Sewed some - read the Monthly & new Independent. Isaac came before supper. Says he is not aware that he has an Enemy on his Div.?. His word is law with all, and the only Gospel with many. I'm glad [[thiys?] have so good.
Completed

Saturday 16
Letter from Eliab & Maria and Anna - all good I went to Mrs Shepards Smith's & Adon? with Abby and baby in his cart Finished dress all but pocket and few stitches more. Isaac sick with Diarrhea. 
Sabbath-17-1 None of us but Abby went to meeting. Mr Rowly said Mr Bird preached finely. Hope his tour East did really do him good and will make him a more useful man. We read Independent unclear Thompson's letter about the Copts. Interesting. Dear Isaac in the bed about all day.
Completed

Monday 18 -

Abby washing - I took care of baby in A.M. and tried to write letter to Lucy - Finished it by night and my dress too - Wonderful for me in these days - Isaac better some today  Now if the naughty ague will only let him alone I will be glad - Why need? a visitor intrude when unwelcome -  Fine shower today - Rowly & Smith here -  O the music of the Katydids after the sun sinks and the moon rises - How distinctly & Emphatically they speak & reply  It is really worth coming west to hear
Completed

Tuesday 19 July -

Mrs Wood? called - looked in the baby's carriage where he slept and said she thought he looked worth "raising" - Rain today about all day - Miss Reynolds here most of afternoon, misses the company & books of her old home  I quilted for baby smne  Letter came from Dun?  How glad I am they are well.  I wrote to Augusta & Lucy & Yarber? & mailed.

Wednesday 20 July -

Rain and sunshine alternate today. I rather like such a day  

in different handwriting:  Miss Paine & Mrs E.N. Smith called & Miss P spent afternoon & bored Isaac about School
Completed

Thursday 21st July

 Mrs. Holt & Emma here most of forenoon. Abba washed and Isaac took care of the baby (didn't)  P.M. went to Ride to R.R. Line Wes? and down by Old Dick Taylor's, then crossing the R.R. Line again, straight through the wood to Du Quoin: on some very bad roads, quite frightful. Found Found Fringed Purple Orchid? and Wild Sensitive Plant on Partridge  Rd.
Completed

Saturday 23 July -

Isaac seems some better today - He stays at the office - baby and I down there in P.M. till Sussns? Twitchell & Crosby arrived - I wrote two pages home, Isaac covered third page - good - Mr & Mrs Keyes rode after supper then she took care of my baby and Isaac & I went and had a good ride - Everybody good & kind - I am thankful I hope - Mrs B. makes my bed, sweeps & does a great many things to help me without being once asked; and when I told her I could do it too -  Read interesting article on Pitcairns Island in Littell -
Completed

Sabbath, 24 July -

Rev Wood preached  - some rain in P.M. These Sabbaths hardly seem like Sabbath. I am afraid I have not grace enough to stay at home from church - I need all the aids? I can have to keep me where I ought to be

Monday 25 July -
Isaac & Mr Keyes left just after Dinner for the Junction. It seemed lonely  I went up and stayed a little while with Mrs. Nellis - Baby good, I cut out a dress for him - wrote some home -
Tuesday 26 July - 
Mailed letter home - Went down to Mrs Keyes. My room had a cleaning & the parlor so I thought it best to be away from the dampness - We both went to Du?..Bahnbanks? in P.M. had a fine time
Completed

getting the babies ready - One would cry & then the other - thus keeping a continual song - sometimes breaking out in full choress - but we finished then at last & started - pleasant ride & good visit - baby never cried or did one naughty thing while we were gone
Wednesday 27 July -

 Mayo eight weeks old this day - grows finely - I read Fowler's books about all day - many good things in them - valuable unclear as I think - which it is well for all to know and practice  Isaac came about noon - me right glad - and he seems as well as when he left Monday  Baby & I went to the office just before supper
Completed

Thursday July 28 -

Isaac gone to Big Muddy - Beautiful day but cool - Mrs Keyes says such weather in this month has not been known for ten or twelve years -  Mr. Post called -

Friday July 29

Isaac went to Fengermus? & called at D. Yattlis? - brought an invitation for me to go there and visit - and brought a "bucket" of apples too -baby & I went riding after supper

Saturday July 30

I went down to the office with baby - he slept till past Eleven - up most of P.M. I almost finished his dress - Isaac is literally covered with tick bites that pester the life out of him with their terrible itching. I pity him - poor help truly?.
Completed

Sabbath July 31 -

Dear, delightful, silent sabbath - come again. "All the World" gone to Vergennes to Quarterly Meeting - except me and I should like to go too, for once -

Monday Aug 1

Baby two months old.  Mrs Campbell's little baby girl is dead, died last night = A few short months it lived in this world of ours - happy one, we might almost say to go so soon where is no shade - where Jesus is the light = yet the parents fond hopes of blighted - the sweet little bud is rent from the stem Ere it had unfolded half its sweetness - wrote to Maria -
Completed

Tuesday August 2 -

Miss Reynolds here all day - A troop of Vergennes people with Mr Binet here in the morning - Did nothing but take care of baby & entertain company all day - It was rainy & shiny like April. Letters from home & sister Lucy - mailed one to ?ar?iers?  Began Shady Side in Eve.  Isaac read loud

Wednesday August 3
Read in Shady Side - baby good as baby need be. Some rain with the sunshine - humming birds & robins all about - I love to hear a robin - it is a real N.E. warbler
Completed

Thursday August 4 -

Finished baby's dress - Read considerable - Miss Paine called at night - took tea and talked of school - Isaac took her paper and went to see the Merchants and talked at them to persuade them to do something - Mr. M. says it is the only thing to preserve the present condition of Du Quoin or present its degenerating doom? - wrote to Jenny -

Friday Aug 5 -

Mr Given? here - Isaac took me to ride two or three miles on the morning after an abortive attempt to go to Little Muddy and meeting Mr G. from there - We went to office in P.M. - Got baby to sleep and read Shady Side in Evening -
Completed

Saturday Aug 6 -

Isaac at home - finished "Shady Side" - Shady truly, so far as this world is concerned - I fear I have neither grace nor patience to bear trial like that portrayed therein -My heart rises in Earnest petition that I may not be tempted above that I am able to bear - But ? the gloreous  crown of those who resist the temptation, Endur(e) patiently the buffettings of the world the hard sayings and doings of those that would do them wrong, secure? all as from God and are victors in the End  Blest are they who have thorough? much tribulation enters? here and wear the crown.
Completed

Sabbath August 7 -

Mrs Keyes took up care of little Mayo and I went to chh. Baby tumbles from his cart going down and was frightened but not hurt - I was troubled too till sure he was safe & sound - Mr B. preached on the Perseverance of Saints a very good sermon. But he seemed to me to be preaching something ? to himself & what he thought was ? to all present -

Mr & Mrs Buck & Dunham came at night - from Mt Hawkins  I wrote about Mr Gages? home -
Completed

Monday August 8 -

How this month is doing! Soon will the harvest be past and the Summer ended.  Sat most the day with Mrs Buck & Nellis - Lay down some in A.M. - finished letter home  Isaac wrote too about going East - Smith, Rowly & Post all here - I believe I do love quiet  nai? theless I love to have the house about full occasionally & enjoy society & conversation But baby is my chief society now and dear little company he is too
Completed

Tuesday August 9 -

Mr & Mrs Buck gone  A very warm day - I did not accomplish much - tended baby & read a little. Mr Smith and I had quite a sing in A.M. -  Isaac & I with baby went riding in P.M. and on the line - had a fine shower but short and umbrela scribbles kept it off. Iron weed in its glory now - very like Canada Thistle.

Wednesday August 10 -

At the office in the A.M. reading  R?..ctnam? - Called at Mrs Roots after tea with Mrs Keyes & Nellis

Thursday 11 August. Warm  warmer  Its as much as one can do to keep the flies off and sit and Endure the heat -
Completed

Friday July 12 -

Wrote a letter to cousin L. Porel? in A.M. - by snatches - M? Smith brought frm? dish of Peaches & Dr W? a glorious pail full  How wonderfully we are cared for! We hardly eat anything else I need to write some to sister Lucy but could not succeed with  but a few lines.

Saturday - 13 -

Went to office & finished letter to Lucy - Isaac wrote to Charles - we mailed both - read some in P.M.

Sabbath 14 -

Mr Bird preached - Isaac read loud Mrs Hemans? & Janis? "Young Mans Guide" - We read together in Frerch? Testament - and Family Testament
Completed

Monday 15 August -

Isaac very busy in A.M. Just after dinner went to Little Muddy in great haste with ragged pockets -

Tuesday 16 August -

Wrote by snatches a long letter to cousin L. Brigham - Mayo good as good can be  Letter came from Mother M. and from Dunbarton - Mother & George-Anna coming to Chicago this month - may come here

Wednesday 17 Aug

Isaac gone to Big Muddy when he came last night from Mt H - he was loaded with nice things - Mud & watermelons, tomatoes, peaches, apples, green? corn, squashes
Completed

and time would fail me to tell all - We had green corn & squash for dinner - too bad he could not share in his own "goodies". But he is in blessing? blessed may  be
Thursday 18 Aug

Isaac went out on the Line West of here  - wanted us to go too but the sun shone too hot - We ate watermelons when he came back and peaches - I never ate so freely of fruit before and it does me no harm that I perceive - Letter came from Augusta -

Friday - 19 -

 I went to Mrs Keyes and ironed some baby dresses in A.M. Mrs Burges quite sick. She overworked - poor woman, the burden of family care and support comes all upon herself and she is too frail to endeavor it -
Completed

Saturday 20 Aug -

I went down to the office and sewed - finished one skirt? for baby while he slept - Letter from Emilia after so long a time - She scolds me summat? & I never mind I have summat? against her - but I dont believe we will make out unclear quarrel after all. Mrs Burgess moved home and Mr & Mrs Keyes again preside at their own table I like Mrs B. but am rather gladish that they have gone  Mr Levenworth here at night.  We had unclear all day today ? noon? or room?. Every thing is mouldy for the dampness thereof - I sat with baby on the porch all afternoon - house all upside down
Completed

Sabbath 21 Aug -

 The rain descends slowly & softly In many heavenly influences fall this day moving many a heart to turn to wisdom's way - Miss Paine called yesterday and I talked with her about school and about Ephriam? Root - She seems gradually sinking to the grove and as yet wholly indifferent - In the soul she must be loved or lost forever just as he himself decides in the brief space of probation - that seems left to him

Monday 22 -

Ironed little in morning - called over to Mrs Burgess' and then over to the office - wrote letter to Emelia  Read some of "Old Morality" - wrote a letter to George in evening -
Completed

Tuesday 23 Aug

Wrote a letter home in A.M. & mailed it - Washed & ironed a little for baby & in P M went up to Mr. Roots with Isaac. It rained some, we stopped a little while at Mrs Morgan's. Stopped over night at Mr Roots  Slept in damp room and took some cold mayhaps

Wednesday 24 -

Fruit of every description for our pleasure is benefit this morning. plums, peaches, apples, melons, grapes &c - Went over to Mr Holt's about nine - Pleasant Yankee house  I had head ache & felt sick all day  - Mrs. Roots rode over at night and sent me some wine afterwards
Completed

Thursday 25 -

Isaac came about noon we called at Mr Roots and then came home. The pleasantist place of all is our Du Quoin

Friday 26 Aug -

Not very well-tired & lazy - Read some - sewed some - lay down good deal

Saturday 27 Aug 

Isaac home in A.M. - up to New Du Quoin in P.M. - I made baby a night gown - he was good as ever baby be all day long

Sabbath 28 Aug

Mr Bird gone - Isaac read the sermon? - Mr Shepherd preached at night -
Completed

Monday 29 Aug -

Made a skirt for Mayo - Isaac at home - Mr Rowley came & brought Mrs Post & Ellen & baby - Stopped till nearly night - came with the Bo's new carriage. McLelland at night - said he had plan? well? in the night many times for the prairie flies - had tied grass over his head on horseback

Tuesday 30 Aug -

Isaac went to Beaucoup with Mr Keyes in P. M. - He wanted me to go but it was too warm & he would be too late home  A thundershower at night -  Isaac said it chased them all the way for 13 miles holding on back side the waggon but they were not hurt at all - about Eight when they came - we had done expecting -

Wed. 31 Aug.

Isaac brought home a  weed from a corn field that was 13 ft 1 inch long - I made little apron for Mayo  Went to ride at night to be? top. Wild plums abundant  gero..a?
Completed

Sabbath Sept 4 -

Went to church in A.M. Isaac stayed with Mayo -

Monday -
wrote home and to Lucy Fankin? and mailed them both. Isaac went up to Little Muddy after din.
Tuesday Sept 6 -

Cut off my hair my self - sewed some - recd newspapers

Wednesday Sep 7 -

Headache - lonely day -

Thursday Sept 8 -

Isaac came before dinner brought me beautiful double balsam - pail of apples from Mr Roots
Completed

Friday - 9 Sept

Isaac home - Missrs Rowley & Post here - I must write mother to rest more - lie down more -  O how would I love to show her as fat? dear little Mayo - I hope we can come? sometime -

Saturday 24 Sept

Two weeks since a word I have written - A long letter came from Anna at Elyria today - containing wondrous tidings - She to be married the first of next month! and Elyria to be her home at present - Dr De Witt, a gentleman in high standing is the bridegroom elect - and Anna thinks they shall visit Illinois and come to look at us in our home - may nothing occur to prevent. How we shall rejoice to see them
Completed

Sabbath 25 Sept.

I did not go to chh and not very well - lay on the bed about all day - wrote some. to Almeida and mother M

Monday 26 Sept

Mailed letters to Almeida, Lucy, Mother M. and Anna - Went to the office all the A. M - Made little apron for Mayo -

Tuesday 27 -

Letter from father, mother & Jenny - flowers from Jenney -  Father had just parted with the last bill, for George, when the X'd reached him - glad he has them -  Cousin Lucy died in St. Charles Sept 17 - I mailed a letter to her Sept 18 in reply to hers dated June 30 - the last she will ever write me  As leaves from trees in Autumn so those who once have trod the green earth
Completed

with me, are passing away -  Thanks to Him who has Redeemed us for dear Lucy's hopes of Heaven and calm reliance on a Saviors merits  The music of another harp is heard in Heaven and another voice in angel strains sings with the blood bought strong -
Wednesday 28

Isaac with Mr Roots all day counting money - He came about noon yesterday with his boy? of gold.

Thursday 29 - 

Mr Keyes & Isaac went to Big Muddy after B.G. Roots had gone - Home again before night - A damp uncomfortable day - letters from home

Friday 30 -

Isaac all day locked in the office with the monies - Could not get away fr. them  Even for dinner - Charles? carried him some - Not home till past ten in Eve. I not sleep till he came -
Completed

Saturday Oct. 1 1853

Mayo four months old this day weighs 14 Lbs. 14 oz. - rather small compared with the huge babies we hear of - His down East cousin at the same age numbered 18 lbs. -

Finished little blue delaine sack for the wee one today - need some of the Scotts "Henilworth"? - Isaac at home all day - No letters for us by this day's post
Sabbath Oct 2-

 My dear Mother's birthday - I ought to write her a letter at least -  Isaac went to chh this A.M. & I went with Mrs Keyes this P.M. Mr Shepherd was expected but cane not - so Mr Bird read an excellent sermon from the National Preacher - I called at Edw Smith's - their little boy had a very bad fit today & is still quite sick - Dear little one - I hope he will soon be well - I wanted to hasten home and look at dear little Mayo and be sure he was well - How thankful we sh'd be for health

on side:  Old Dr Bradshaw at Mr Smiths
Completed

Monday Oct 3 -

Isaac went to Little Muddy - I mended and read in forenoon while Mayo slept  In P.M. lay down to rest and then we all went on a grape gathering expedition to the wood - The girls took all care of Mayo; so I felt at ease and enjoyed the trip much - tall oak trees laden to the topmost boughs with the pretty clusters - We gathered flowers too - I laid them in Mayo's carriage all around him  He the sweetest flower of all & as quiet and good as need be, cooing to himself while we plucked the purple fruit - Johnny Nellis screamed at the top of his voice about all the time - was afraid to ride with Ghetty in the little wagon -  O dear me - wonder if Mayo will grow to be naughty & willful. How shall I know how to teach him to be good  May I be taught -   Mayo's first toy came today - a little rubber ring - He amuses himself with it - holds it in both hands to bite it! -
Completed

Tuesday Oct 4 -

Isaac came about noon, and we went to ride before he unharnessed the nags - I commenced baby's cloak {blue flannel} - mended coat & c -

Wednesday Oct 5 -

Rode with Isaac up to Du Quoin this afternoon - down at the office in A.M. wrote some home this evening -

Thursday 6 Oct -

Wrote some home & mailed the letter with one to Mary Bailey. Letter came from Lucy - telling ? Oh's & Ahs of wonder about news from Anna -

Friday 7 Oct -

Put trimming on babys cloak - finished "Kenilworth" - Mrs Keyes and I went out leaving baby with Emeline  & Chester with Ann - We made four calls at Dr Walls - G. Smiths - H? & M. Hinckleys  Little Sirrin? ran out with peaches for me
Completed
Completed

Monday Oct 10-1853-

Isaac home all day - Mr Rowley here - amazing dull - something or somebody ails him - He tried to carve roast beef at dinner and upset mustard and pepper - poor dear creture? - He meant to do it so nice I felt sorry for him -

Tuesday oct 11 -

Mrs Das called to hear melodian  Mrs E. Smith called and Winser? - He is nearly well - Isaac at home - Smith arrived afternoon  Rowley here too - Isaac carried me to ride over to Mrs. Fulton's - Had quite a sing in Evening - I did not feel very well all day - Mr E? Roots sent me nice apple -

Wednesday Oct 12 -

We hoped it would rain today but there was only a wee bit - shower - both cisterns empty & I cannot drink the well water - It is like unto a dose of salts -
Completed

Isaac gone to Big Muddy with Rowley & Smith - Mr Holt called and left big apples - I never saw so large ones  Smith back home tonight -
Thursday 13 Oct -

Isaac with Mr Smith left for the junction - I did not feel very well - Mr Lyman from Chester called He & wife will be here tomorrow to dine  Letter came from home - mother & Jenny - The letter improving in penmanship & composition - I wrote some to her in Evening -

Friday 14 Oct. }

Mrs Lyman came soon after breakfast - a jolly well condition? free & easy person - kind & motherly withal? - just returned from a tour to New Eng - visited the Chrystal Palace - Mr L. in to dinner - said he knew Mr Metcalf - took him to Mr Roots when he first came to Illinois - I hope Isaac will get home to see him -
Completed

In afternoon I went with Mrs Keyes to Mr Hinckley's to visit - Met Mrs Wall there - very pleasant time - her & Mrs L. spent night here -
Saturday 15 Oct -

Sewed a little, read some - Mrs L. here in P.M. - her Taylor or "Uncle Dick" came in to hear the melodian - Thought he never heard such music before "He felt mighty slim & puny - but such music every day he reckoned would do him a heap of good" "He was just getting over a spell of sickness" - The most comical specim.. of a unclear genuine going Sucker I have seen -

Sabbath 16 -

A miserable little chill this morning followed by slight fever and headache - If I only recover from it without making Mayo sick how glad I will be
Completed

Monday 17 Oct

Felt better today - Isaac at home - baby seems well as usual - been taking Quinine - Do not feel like eating - We are having Yankee pumpkin pies now - had them about two weeks they taste good - Frost has not harmed the tomato vines yet - A beautiful monthly rose in bloom today and more buds on the bush - That bush is a treasure - The sweet scented honeysuckle too, yet in bloom  Plenty of purple and white Asters and Solidago in the thicket - sociable yellow butterflies still linger round the last flowers - The more gorgious ones have said good bye -

Note: Solidago is Goldenrod
Completed

Tuesday 18 -

Same headache too day no return of chill. Thanks to Isaac & Quinine - Isaac gone to Big Muddy. Mr Rowley called on his way north - will go to Chicago before we see him again  Blue birds & cat birds begun to come nearer the dwellings now  the handsome Blue Jay descens? from the walnut and hawthorne to the door. The golden autumnnal days are here in all their magnificence - Who could but enjoy them - - Isaac, Crosby & Mitchell here tonight -  Sent letters home fr. Isaac to parents - me to Jenny - also from us both to Lucy -
Completed

Wednesday Oct 19 - }

Isaac started for Junction & may meet Col. Nason & c  gathered boquet of youth & old age, honeysuckle, cedar, and the red bud vessels of sweet briar -  making another little sack for Mayo - dear little humming bird.  Showers of leaves come pattering down  Do they wail that life is so short, or is their whispering a murmur of gladness that their work is done, and they may rest: The wood grow more georgeous & brilliant every day -  Every shade of yellow, red, orange, russet & brown - Some clear bright green yet remains - The deep shade of the evergreens is wanting on the  western forests - lively maples too   Chill at night -
Completed

Thursday Oct. 20

Isaac came unexpectadly home about noon - I was glad enough to see him -

Friday oct 21 -

Isaac at home - We went to ride short distance - trees look finely - Oaks are a lively red and brick color at the Edges with a center of clear bright green

Saturday Oct 22 -

No letters for us - nothing from Anna  What means it? Hope nothing will veto their projected visit - Isaac says he dars not think they will come - They will find all sick at Peru & vicinity and will suppose the case as bad at least here - & think it best not to venture -  I hope he will prove a false prophet about it  He is gone to Big Muddy today -  Dear little Mayo seems to have some cold - a little feverish - It is hard to think my bad feelings must make suffering for him
Completed

Sabbath Oct 23, 1853

Cold & windy today  Ettie? or Wie? staid at home all day  Isaac at Morning Service & S. School  Baby not very well & rather troublesome   Mr Bird gone to Lysiot? & Elders too  Meeting conducted by Geo  Burbank, Sermon Life, Not Death - the Motive to Religion.
Completed

Tuesday - 25 Oct.

Isaac waited till almost night for the mail and after reading the letter it brought from Anna started in haste for the Junction - hoping to meet Col. Nason - I finished baby's hood - knitted of red worsted. Mrs Nellis gave me silk to line it. Mrs McCoy called - said Sarah Button? whom we expected to take care of Mayo had fallen & hurt her arm - may not be able to come for some time - sorry for Emmeline seems to have plenty to do for Mrs Keyes without helping me any -  Trees almost done - heavy frost last night - poor rose droops & fades - probably the last we shall have - The falling leaves disclose many a birds nest clinging to the naked limbs of the trees -
Completed

Wednesday 26 Oct -

 Went to walk a short distance Mrs Keyes sat sewing with me most of the day - Mr Buck, wife and her mother came at night - I paid him some money  Isaac left and took receipt -

Thursday 27 Oct.

Letter came from home - some hair of Achsas baby in it - Dull, rainy day cold too. Mr Buck took some of Isaac's woolen socks to keep his feet warm -  I wrote to George to be ready for Saturdays mail

Friday 28 Oct -

Pleasant and warmer - One more monthly rose in bloom - Wrote to Anna DeWitt   Mrs Whiny? & baby here - not six months old and can stand alone.
Completed

Saturday 29 Oct.

Isaac home about noon brought wagon load of apples very fine winter ones - cow did not eat them -  Mr Smith here to dinner Isaac took us to ride -  had a fine time. Some oaks are still bright & green - Met Mrs Fulton & Sarah - The latter coming here Monday to take care of Mayo -

Sabbath 30 Oct.

Fine, still morning - cool but bright & sunny - I went to meeting and Isaac stayed home with Mayo - Excellent sermon "Secret things belong to God" - What thou knowest not now thou shalt know hereafter - Isaac wrote to Lucy, to Charles to come out home & to Eliab -  squiggle
Completed

Monday 31 Oct.

Sent letters written yesterday Sent for "Musical World" ($3 00) and for "Hydropathic Review"  How many good things we have  Fine breezy morning - Isaac going to Bib Muddy - Sarah Fulton came to be Mayo's murhes?  I commenced "Headlings Letters from Italy" - Hope we can see Isaac J. Hopper? sometime - The papers extol it - so? also lens? Torrey's book, "City & Country Life"  We saved a big apple for Anna - but will go in quick consumption non? In? thinking it measured   I read of an ear of corn raised in Madison Co. containing 1 1/2 pint of corn   Made part of an apron for Ghetty - finish? Mayo & delaine Sack -
Completed

Tuesday Nov 1 -

Sarah went to school for the forenoon  Isaac took us to the Depot  fine ride Beautiful as could be desired. Mr & Mrs Keyes started for St Louis to be gone a week  Miss Burbank called in P.M.  We went to the office afterwards - Isaac has more than $1300 dollars worth of land beside the farm by the Station. 13 - 40 acre lots and a little over -  Very tall man with wife to match came to put up for the night - A Beautiful rose in blossom today - Mayo five months old - nearly 17 Lbs.

Wednesday Nov 2 -

Made little sack shirt for DuCoigne    Isaac at home in office - wrote some in letters home & to Anna - Baptist men thru here have to stop for night on way to Convention some six miles north - Much amused at conversation during evening
Completed

Thursday, November 3 -

Mailed letters home and to Anna - received some from Mother M. Lucy Garber? and Lucy Pond? All expect we have seen the new brother-in-law  Mr Roots here to dinner  Isaac at home -

Friday Nov 4-

Went to Depot and round by Elder Haguler's? meetinghuse - fine scene about the church, worth going to  See only an opening in the thick woods about the church and hordes with sa??tick?  saddlebck?, wagons with five or six chains in each tier? through the woods as far as one could see. Quite picturesque   Mr Seaver here at night - 

on side: saw splendid quail on fence
Sabbath. Nov 6 -

I went to meeting in A.M. Isaac did not go out, not well -
Completed

Monday Nov 7 -

Wrote to Lucy & mother M Mailed letters at night to be ready for early start in morn.

Tuesday Nov 8.

Rainy some - Isaac gone - Mrs Fulton sent for Sarah to come home tomorrow.

Wednesday Nov 9 -

 Pleasant. Sarah home all day. Isaac stayed in house and helped take care of Mayo - indeed took about all the care of him - How good he is -

Thursday Nov 10 -

Pleasant day - Mr & Mrs Keyes not home yet. Neither of us very well - letter came from home - Mother and Jenney - All well as usual  How good to hear such tidings -
Completed

Friday Nov 11 -

Mr & Mrs Keyes came at night after we had done looking for them - detained by business - All well - and we are glad to see them -

Saturday Nov 12 -

Baby had present of a nice India Rubber Rattle from Ghetty - John a ?oy & dog - All in high glee about the new toys - Mrs Keyes brought all I sent for - Paid her $6.15 for all including delain for socks & piece of chambray that I had some time since -  I began to keep regular acct. today  Hope not to be interrupted again - in the discharge of my financial duties -  Saw splendid red headed woodpecker today - One rose bud yet remains on the monthley -
Completed

Sabbath - Nov 13

I went to hear Mr Shepherd at three o'clock . Mr Bird gone & no preaching in A.M. Isaac to unwell to go out at all

Monday Nov 14 -

Pleasant morn  Isaac gone to Big Muddy - I writing home -

Tuesday Nov 15 -

In afternoon Isaac left for the Junction. Pleasant day. I finished a red print dress for Mayo - He is just five & a half months old today.

Wednesday Nov 16 -

I read Hadley's? letters and lay on my back most of A.M.  Mrs Keyes and I called at B. Spragus? to see Mrs Jackson - a quiet pleasant lady just like her sister - Called at H. Smiths & Mr Burgess - Musquitos as troublesome as any time in summer tonight
Completed

Thursday Nov 17 -

Warm as a New England summer day. A Daguerotype artist has been here some time boarding - Elderly - very agreeable - told Mrs Keyes today he had no home since his parents had died - some brothers & sisters - one in Newport Ky - and one in Clinton Ill. A native of Ky. Isaac came late at night and DWC Rowly.

Friday Nov 18 -.

I went with Isaac beloved? to the Depot in A M. Had fine ride Went over to daguerrotype rooms and got a picture of baby - better than I imagined we should get - His hands and feet in so constant motion it seemed about impossible  Think we will try again some day
Completed

Sabbath Nov 20 -

Col. Nason arrived while we were at meeting, from the North - Isaac & I both went & Sarah took care of Mayo - Miss Gannet? and her cousin Miss Noyes at meeting  Mr Bird is to take them to Jonesboro whither go they to teach - Their appearnce did not very favorably impress - quite untastefully dressed according to my ideas with some effort at display -

Monday Nov 21 -

Misses Paine and Reynolds called to see Mr Nason and get help for the Semenaire but he with Isaac had started south - the? which they regretted exceedingly - not so we  Thunder & wind with rain today warm as summer -
Completed

Tuesday Nov 22 -

Warm & pleasant - We went to ride - I sat long time in the porch sewing in the sun -

Wednesday Nov 23 -

I rested in A.M. Preparatory to a ride to Mr Hawkins in aftern  Fine ride - pleasant & warmer -  Called at Mr Roots and ate apples and were urged to Thanksgiving dinner the next day - Went over to Mr Holt's and spent the night - Seemed very glad to see us indeed -

Thursday Nov 24 - Thanksgiving

Too windy for us to go on up to Little Muddy so we were left at Mr. Roots for the day - Even? Mr & Mrs Holt, Old Mr Winthrop, Dollins? Dunham & c all there at dinner. Turkey, Chicken, Goose
Completed

& Sheep, & Pumpkin Turnips - Potato Bis & Cakes - a loaded table - all tasted good and homelike I felt tired in Afternoon
Friday Nov 25 -

Cold, chilly morn. Letters from home - George &c   I did not feel very well and we started late for Du Quoin, but were not long in coming home - Horse race on the prairie Great collection of people to witness it. Looked good and homelike when we got here - Home is a good place

Saturday Nov. 26

Not very well - Isaac quite sick not up till afternoon - Letters from Lucy Y? & from Emeline Putnam - Picture from "Musical World" of W. Vincent Wallace - Composer of Music  No Col. Nason tonight.  Baby some feverish - taken cold - gums sore.
Completed

Sabbath 27 Nov -

None of us went to meeting. It was the Methodist Quarterly - house crowded full - Isaac about sick & little Mayo too - Mayo has very bad cold -  Smith & Ketchel & Given all here  Col Nason not here as expected

Monday - 28 - Nov -

Messenger from Col Nason - He dines this day at Mt Hawkins - Isaac goes to meet him and traverse with him the North of the Div. will be gone about all the? week - I wrote long letters to Lucy Y? in evening. Mayo required much attention but is better. Rain in P.M. and in the night.

Tuesday 29 Nov.

No mail today. Mail here is changable as wind. Mr Dunning brought wife & baby to board. I sent my washng?
Completed

a doz.? over to Mrs. Fulton - Mrs Keyes has done it since 22 Aug -
Wednesday 30 Nov

Mayo better but troublesome - Warm & cloudy today - some rain -

Thursday Dec 1 -

Mayo six months old   Isaac came home about noon  found no mail and started immediately to Gattoways? to get it.  Took my five letters  one to Lucy Garber? one home -

Friday Dec 2 -

Real wintry day - freezing some. No day so cold before - Isaac went to Big Muddy - I hunted some mutton for the Irish ? - He thanked and God blessed us. "May you go to heaven" said he - Isaac says he is a bore talks too much for his convenience -
Completed

Sabbath - Dec 4

Isaac went to church - we both decided it not best to have dear little Mayo with Sarah but one of us always to remain at home - some duties are paramount even to church going -

Saturday Dec 10.

Beautiful weather all the last week - some frosty mornings but mild bright days - Italy may boast her beautiful skies but I believe none can be more lovely & glorious than overspread us here in our own America -  Mr Smith here & Post. We tried again for Mayos picture but not a second would the rogue be quiet
Completed

Sabbath Dec 11 -

A dear delightful day - We both went to church and took Mayo to be christened - He did not cry at all but he was in too much glee to be quiet - Mr Birds sermon was on the nature & design of baptism It was very good indeed - The little one was called "Ducoign Mayo"  We have given him to our God and our father's God and by our act promised to train him for God & heaven - Daily & hourly may we remember this delightful, this fearful duty. The hymn sung was
O Lord Encouraged by thy grace
We bring our infant to thy throne
Completed

Monday Dec 12 -

Isaac at home - We called at Mr Fairbanks - and bought $200 worth Bibles & c - Isaac a Pocket Testament for himself and book of Prov. for me  He went up to the depot - afterwords Mr J.C. Smith here all day - O.G. Roots came with money about eight in Eve. I wrote home and to Lucy Farber. Sarah was home all day and I felt bad and weak. Mary Wilson came to help Mrs Keyes  Major came at night.

Tuesday Dec 13

Isaac left for Richmond & Smith for Big Muddy - Mr. Dunning came at night - and made his wife happy - Charlie would not go to him nor look at him without crying - too bad! altogether - I do hope Mayo will never be afraid of his own dear father - mailed letter home & to Lucy - Mended? after the mice - the scoundrels
Completed

Wednesday 14 Dec

Sarah came yesterday noon Said her mother had so much work she would like her at home when I could get another girl - I must try to get word to Emmeline.

Thursday 15 Dec -

Everything looks glorious - like a fairy creation - The hoar frost covers all - Every leaf & twig is silvered -   Abby Wilson called today & brought me some apples. I Engaged her to come here next week - I prefer her to Emmeline and am glad to get her -  Isaac come home before night -

16 Dec Friday -

Isaac gone to Big M. I knit a pair of socks for Mayo  Read Haryson's Dec? -
Completed

Saturday Dec 17 -

Snowed in the morning and it melted by night - Charles came - O how glad we were to see him - brought card and ribbon from Anne - Spend preceding Sabbath with her

Sabbath Dec 18 -

Mr B. preached on mode? of baptism - Charles & Isaac went - Snowed finely in afternoon  Mr R. Stewart preached at three oclock - Messrs Smith & Stotts here to dinner - Stotts could not stay because his clothes were not good enough - Charles come into our room and wrote and we had a fine long chat - So good! Seemed like seeing the whole family almost - Isaac wrote Lucy  Eliab  Mother M - I wrote nobody.
Completed

Monday Dec 19 -

Mr Rowley came fresh & ?right? - Isaac went to Big M and carried Charles & left him  ? home at night - Mr Rowley brought "Homes in New World" & Isaac T. Hopper that we sent for and gold pen & pencil case for Isaac  He brought me as Christmas present - Hadley's "Mary Queen of Scots" & "Lyrics from the Wide Wide World" - both tasteful pretty & good - We had social time in evening - Sarah Button finishes seven weeks today - Abby Wilson came to take her place -

Tuesday 20 Dec -

Splendid day - Isaac not well - baby not well - self not well. Live in hope - Abby gone to Mr H Hinckleys to wash for sake of soft water - brought me a nice apple  Letter fr. home & from Cather? -
Completed

Wednesday 21 Dec -

Rather cloudy - Isaac at home on bed most of the day - In about the same condition myself - Glad Abby is home to keep dear little Mayo -  I wrote about three pages to Anna - but did not nearly answer her good letter -  Isaac went to talk with Dr W about me and my malady? He concluded I had better live on bread & milk even if we had to buy a cow ourselves  I like the prescription much but know not where the animal is to be found  We read some in Isaac T. Hopper and some in Miss Bremer'sbook - both very Entertaining -
Completed

Thursday 22 Dec -

Mailed letter to Anna & Daguerreotype of baby to Father & Mother - Dull, damp day -

Friday 23 Dec -

Not very well - Bright beautiful day. Fine bracing air - Would do me good if I had strength to stay out and breathe it

Saturday 24 Dec -

On bed about all day - Mr & Mrs Dunning went to Mr. Hawkins - Charles came in evening with Isaac from Big Muddy - The people made candy in the evening but it burned some - Sent Anna and Martha Elisabeth little ball baskets  Saw Anna Skipworth work baskets with thread, needles, pins, buttons - and testament to Mary Wilson - to Abby - basket with needles pins  & c
Completed

Sabbath 25 Dec -

Isaac & Charles went to meeting - Abby at home - I all day on bed - Isaac read to me -

Wednesday 26 Dec -

Splendid day - I better I think - Mr J.G. Smith came up sick chills & fever - The strong man bowed down - Such a frame as his and the weakness of a child! Dr. Wall came to see him and looked in upon me - Thinks my symptoms indicate nothing of Dispepsy or indigestion but merely general depletion and some nervous affection cansid? thereby - Will prepare for me Carbonate of Iron -  Isaac home all day - Dr says he should advise me to wean little Mayo at least not nurse till I am stronger  Dear little boy - if he only keep well!
Completed

Tuesday 27 Dec -

Feel better today - began the Iron - good medicine to take - tastes like dirt precisely - Mr Smith much fever - feels badly - Isaac, dear good Isaac stays at home for me though he intended going away today - such a friend - thanks for him - He has this morning written a whole letter of hardly anything but little items for me to send home - It was the regular time to send and I could not prepare the letter very well  He wrote considerable about little Mayo though that was important -  Little Mayo does not nurse  Isaac takes care of him at night and succeeds finely - only he needs the sleep - He works hard and long and I am sorry he cannot rest in quiet - It troubles me -
Completed

Thursday 29 Dec -

Fine day - I feel comfortable Been outdoors two or three times  Made little flower basket & book mark for Lirren? Wall -

Friday 30 Dec -

Charles came up - seems perfectly well -

Saturday 31 Dec -

Last day of the year - Isaac gone to De Soto - Snowed some in afternoon but star light eve. No letters today - Isaac sent for Hydropathic Cook Book & c - Bought quite a parcel more books to give away of Mr Burbank - One to Abby - Practical Rites?, to Skinner Young Christian  Little day book to Mrs Keyes   Dunning & Nellis -  Gallandets & Charles Rich
Completed

books to Ellen Wall &  Harriet Smith  Milk for babes to Ann Adams & c
Sabbath Jan 1. 1854

Quite a winter - ground white with the pretty flakes  So cold snow remained all day  Isaac stayed with me & baby & Abby went to meeting -    Read Gan?  Mess.? & Child's Paper through - Isaac gave me Daily Scripture Expositor - I love it.  Mayo seven months old

Monday Jan 2 -

I taking medicine - Carbonate of Iron - Dr in about every day -

Tuesday Jan 3 -

Letter came from Lucy Garber?  I read Homes of the New World -
Completed

Thursday Jan 5 -

Mrs Holt & Emma here - brought some Sweet russet apples, very nice - Fine weather still continues - Little Mayo's cheeks grow ruddy - Weaning seems to be good for him -

Friday Jan 6 -

Pleasant days still. I walk out every day - I gain a little -

Saturday Jan 7 -

Charles came - We mailed letter to Lucy Farber? - I wrote four pages of a small sheet to her yesterday - Isaac covered a sheet to her & Eliab to send with it

Sabbath Jan 8 -

Loveliest of days - like a May day - Isaac walked out with me - Read Home Missionary to me and wrote two pages to Dunton Me -  {Maine}
Completed

Monday Jan 9 -

Bright sunny day - Isaac gone to Richmond with Mr. Fox, the new Engineer arrived Saturday - will not be home tonight -

Tuesday Jan 10 -

Mailed letter to Dunbarton - Isaac wrote part & Infant - Received a letter from Dunbarton also - from Mother - She has a return of her bad cough - George has done school and gone back to Meriden - not very well - How we are reminded that we are all frail - What id Death? What is Life?   Isaac came home tonight -  brought me a big orange from Mrs. Roots - Little Mayo not well - Isaac waked some twenty times certainly during the night - dear Isaac - he has the hard time & good time.
Completed

Wednesday 11 Jan -

Rainy day - new times altogeth.. hope all the cisterns will be filled but it does not rain very fast yet -  I wrote a letter home to sick moth[er] to comfort her - Isaac all day at office  Mayo some better I hope

Thursday 12 Jan -

Charles here at night - Isaac busy in office all day long - till ten at night - Little Mayo restless all night - I mailed short letter home to Mother -

Friday 13 Jan -

Little Mayo not so well - Isaac gone to Big Muddy but home about the middle of P.M. - Sent for Dr W at night - to see little Mayo - Gave him Calomel -
Completed

Saturday Jan 14 -

Mayo better - coughs good deal  No letters today - Charles came. Mr Samuel Conant - a cousin of Isaac came last night - tired and lame with unusual walking  We did not find him  out till this morning -

Sabbath 15 Jan -

Dr came in to see Mayo - thinks he may not require more medicine  Mr Bird preached long and ?ny? on Infant Baptism - House full of men today - R.R. men and travelling Lecturers -

Monday 16 Jan -

Men mostly obliged to remain on account of weather - rain, sleet and hail all day - In the sunshine everything would be glittering - Isaac in office - Mr. Post here all night - Abby four weeks today  Pd. $5.00
Completed

Tuesday 17 Jan -

Letter came from mother fathr & Jenney - all good - I went to the office after dinner. We dined about two. Gutters? springing about today on the slippery ground. Mayo better  Tolerably comfortable day today - Men about all left -

Thursday 19 Jan -

Isaac at home - I walked down to the office -

Friday 20 Jan -

Clear, cold & bright day - I have headache and had yesterday - nervous affection I think, forces me to sit and do nothing - I have little  patience to do so, but I must learn to have some
Completed

Saturday 21 Jan -

Still cold - Zero in the morn but bright & clear. Isaac went away on the line - came home about four and I went to ride - thought I should be cold but it seemed only just the air to sent me -  fine bracing and homelike?  I cannot walk much - my limbs swell some and are soon tired - Letter from Mother M? - Charles & Samuel came at night & Mitchel & Dunnng - small company for our Sabbath. Glad of it. Wrote a sheet to Mother M? in evening.
Completed

Sabbath Jan 22 -

Pleasant. Isaac went to meeting in A.M. Abby could have gone at three but dinner was too late. Very quiet day - fewer here than usual.  Isaac read Independent to me

Monday, Jan 23 -

Another fine day - I went to the office to see Isaac; but so many teamsters and stone layers  well-diggers & wallers appeared I could hardly look at him - Mayo much better - good as can be. Wrote long letter home to Dun. Isaac wrote some too. Isaac wrote to Anna to ascertain when she goes East - I do hope Isaac can go all the way with me?, but I must not be naughty about it.
Completed

Tuesday Jan 24 -

Isaac went away early in the morning to be gone ?orth? three or four days - Wont I be glad to see him back -  Mrs. Hiram Hinckley called in P.M. I like her very much a most excellent woman - I sewed some on Isaac's shirt. My sewing when will it be did! I know not.  Mayo went to sleep and Abby was out ironing in evening - Me alone  Mayo only waked at one and half past four - was good boy as usual - cried a little before he went to sleep again - - {Miss Reynolds called.}

Wednesday Jan 25 -

Ann went home - I gave her papers and books for the children - Warmer today. Sewed & knit a little. No gentlemen were ?inar? morning - No body but Ladies at supper table - Mr Keyes came after we retired -  Isaac came after

on side: Gentleman from Jonesboro {charge of track laying} & traveling tablecloth vendor here
Completed

Thursday 26 Jan -

Isaac at home all day - Horses harnessed once to go but St Louis team came and he went not -

Friday 27 Jan -

Isaac went to Big Muddy - P.K. Roots came to see him and another man from above Richmond  Both waited till he came - I wrote to Emelin in the evening -

Saturday 28 Jan -

Mailed letter to Emilin - Recent one from Lorrin Hatch at Atlanta Ga  Gone all A.M. over to "six mile" with Isaac.  Read "Home for all" -

Sabbath 29 Jan -

Dear Isaac 32 years old today - Peter Hlagullyr? - Baptist - preached  Isaac & Abby both went - I took care of little Mayo
Completed

Monday 30 Jan -

Pleasant morning and Isaac was going to take me to the Station at Du Quoin but it grew windy and he left me - Charles came home with him - Abby washed.  We made candy in Evening - good. Called Mrs McCoy's.  Dr. W. brought me more medicine

Tuesday 31 Jan -

Isaac went to Big Muddy - Col. Nason came about noon and waited till night when Isaac came. Smith came at night - Beautiful day warm as Summer - Letter from Eliab -

Wednesday Feb 1, 1854 -

Isaac went to Little Muddy with Col. Nason. Pleasant day, warm -  Mr Peck & Thiry? called. I made flannel skirt. Read first Chap. in D'l Allem...?  Mitchel here at night - No other gentlemen - Mayo eight months old.
Completed

Thursday Feb 2  - 1854

No letters - two or three papers - Isaac home in afternoon - brought me big apple from Mrs Roots - Went in afternoon over to the Line - home at night -

Friday Feb 3 - 1854

Isaac went over to the Station and I went with him - fine day & fine ride - These outings in the fresh bracing air do me good - Mr. Kingsbury home.

Saturday Feb 4 -1854 -

Over to the office with Isaac in A.M. Letter from Lucy & from Mother M - Dunbarton  Isaac sent $1.00 for me to the Guardian Soc. I rode over to "Six mile" in P.M. Saw track laying - 100 men at work -
Completed

Sabbath - 5 Feb.

Wrote letter to Dun. Isaac wrote to Eliab. I went to meeting for the first time since Mayo was baptised - Mr Birds subject - The Devil -

Monday 6 Feb -

 Isaac gone to Big Muddy all day - No gentlemen here - Five Irish travelers came at night - I cut out Mayo an apron - me nightcaps and chemise

Tuesday 7 Feb -

Mailed letter home - Sweet home    Isaac in office - Real rainy day - Cistern filling up finally - Mitchel & Charles here at night - Mary in trouble about something Ann told her I said Mrs Keyes said about her - Little things are great ones, truly -
Completed

Wednesday Feb 8 -

Rainy still - 3 peaject? before breakfast - to Charles? - Little Mayo restless last night - I am afraid I do not all for his health I ought to do. "What it is" to hear Mother & how much it involves - Abby went to see her Mother today - Mary went home to stay - I took care of Mayo, good boy.  Isaac in office in A M - went to Du Quoin in P.M. Pleasant afternoon.  Wrote to Sister Lucy and to br. George - Mr Dunning came at night -

Thursday Feb 9 -

Sent the letters last eve prepared and "Isaac T. Hopper" to Dunbarton.   Isaac in office - Went to ride in P M. I drove most of the time - Isaac held Mayo - Saw ducks in Black Sop? - I was afraid of the water - Abby washed.
Completed

Friday 10 Feb -

Sat with Mrs Nellis most of A M  Abby ironed - I sewed on chemise.  Isaac home all evening & we read - Mr Dunning came up from Big Muddy, and Smith with him. Smith &  Isaac went in Ph? over to Depot.

Saturday 11 Feb -

Mr Dunning left this morn. Smith is to remain over Sabbath - An Ingathering as usual at night. Charles & Samuel, Major  Mr Nellis  Rowley & Smith - a stranger from St Louis   Mary Bird & her sister came - Mrs Peck came to hear melodian - Mr Smith sung bass for me - Read Hydropathic Review  Mrs Keyes busy all day - gets provoked at poor little "Ghetty" every few minutes. She loves the books & papers - & is full of mischief  O if I may but be a good, kind, gentle patient mother - govern myself a well as my  Mayo -  Isaac has sore arm & hands
Completed

Sabbath 12 Feb -

I went to meeting - Text "Am I my brother's keeper?"  Very good. Rather diffuse - Abby had toothache and did not go to meeting -

Monday 13 Feb 

Gentlemen all left before night except Mr Metcalf - he thinks to go to Little Muddy in the morning -  Mild beautiful day. Mrs Keyes and I went to call on Mrs Eatien, Adams, McCoy & Williams - Did not feel much tired after the walking. I must be growing stronger

Tuesday 14 Feb

Rainy -  Isaac did not go to Muddy as he expected - He and I mended gloves till about eleven A M  Had Wild Ducks for dinner - had some Sabbath day also - nice -
Completed

Wednesday 15 Feb

 Isaac went to Big Muddy - Mr Kingsbury came after dinner and remained to see  Isaac. Mrs Nellis thinks to leave soon - perhaps next week -

Thursday 16 Feb.

 Isaac  left for the North - to be gone all the week - Mrs Nellis  fitted dress for me - I am reading "Mary Queen of Scots" Not a letter or a paper for us today.

Friday 17 Feb

Bright frosty morning - Mayo slept all night long - No men save Mr Kelly here last night  I sewed & read and ran about the lot and in P.M. called on Mrs. Shepherd who has fine babe. Also on Mrs Burgess and Mrs Jackson  Wrote to Cather? McK. in evening -
Completed

Saturday 18 Feb -

Letter from Home - George home again sick or not well - Is not going back to Meriden - Letter also from Sister Lucy   Isaac reached home just after supper - Charles came - Samuel not.

Sabbath 19 Feb

 Isaac read sermon on half day heavens? - Mr Bird not well   Isaac began letter to Lucy -

Monday 20 Feb -

I went to the office nearly all day - P.M. copied bills & receipts for  Isaac. We very busy - Warm beautiful day. I wrote to brother at Dunbarton and to Lucy sister for morrow mail - And a note to send Mrs Willard at Jonestown  by  Isaac
Completed

Tuesday 21 Feb -

 Isaac started for Jonesboro to be away the week - I read & sewed and walked out doors - Abby washed & I took care of baby in A.M. Letter came from Anna - She asks us to spend some weeks with her on our way East and go with them in June - Good sister that she is  Irishman came for four spiking hammers - Mr Hinckly took key out got them for him; Letter from a Mr Baker for  Isaac wanting pay. Letter from Calhoun by mail -  Lovely day - warm as May - birds singing sweetly - Hope  Isaac will have a week of good days in all respects -

Wednesday 22 Feb

Major's came at night - so we not alone
Completed

Thursday 23 Feb

Fine day - Abby cleaned out the room - sent Mayo & me upstairs to be out of the way - In P M Mrs Keyes carried us down to  Mrs E Burbanks and Mr Hincklys  Mrs B's two months old baby about as big as Mayo - Mail came while we were gone - brought papers, and letters from Chicago &c - Majors here tonight also
Completed

Saturday 25 Feb

 Isaac & Smith came in the afternoon -  Isaac had good journey - Saw Mrs Ashley - Mrs Willard, Kaley  &c Busy in office till eve - Charles came as usual. No letters from Maine -

Sabbath 26 Feb

Rainy -  Isaac went to meeting - very few out. We read Independent together - an excellent paper it is - We had a quiet day - only Charles & Mr Smith & Major here. Neither Mr Keyes, Nellis, or Mitchell came - or Mr Conant -

Monday 27 Feb -

 Isaac off for Little Muddy with Smith Dull, cloudy day but not rainy - I finished letter to Albina? for the mail - Mayo good all day - dear little one May God bless him always - May good angels watch him this night - precious innocent - Heaven keep him so -
Completed

Tuesday Feb 28 -

Hail, all hail this lovely morning - I have been our a few moments to enjoy the glory -  C?us? of life were all around me. I heard the cat bird's scream, sweet, whistle & the tap, tap tapping of the woodpecker - all rejoicing in returning sunshine. I think too the lowing of cattle, the rattle of wheels in the street the distant whistle of the locomotive and the low hoarse bass of the prairie fowl, booming through the clean air - Mankind & nature had been sleeping and now all, ? fasshed?, awake to life. How more than brutish 'tis for man to walk abroad on such a morning and in all the beauty & the mystery round him - the opening bud of Spring time, the glittering drop of dew, the just appearing verdine? beneath his feet and the boundless blue above to - see not the finger of Almighty God - O the happiness the joy of viewing "All things in God" -
Completed

Wednesday March 1st

 Isaac came yesterday about noon brought mail with Letter from home & from cousin Lucy - Mayo nine months old today - weighs merely 21 Lbs.  Dull cloudy day -  Isaac started for Big Muddy but came home and the rain kept him here.

Thursday March 2

Rainy -  Isaac started again and came back barring the ?ois? cannot - Bad weather this for the Rail Roaders - No letters today for us

Friday 3d March

 Isaac went to Big Muddy - and home at night - Mr Holt came for keys - Charles came also to to office. I mended pants for Mr Kelly & cut out brown linen sack and shirt for  Isaac - Mr Kelly very glad of pants - "He should want no more for a twelve month", "I thank you ma'am - Mrs. Metcalf - may you live long forever and have good health & prosperity & never want."
Completed

Saturday 4th March

Fine day - I rode Gelin? &  Isaac, Dich? as far as Black Sop? then Isaac went on to the Station - Crosby & Mitchel came - No letters for us only one for  Isaac from Curlen?,  Major here & Mr Nellis - I finished Mary Queen of Scots.

Sabbath 5 March

Communion day -  Isaac & Abby went to church in A M -  Isaac & I in P M. I wrote some home

Monday 6 March

Rainy -  Isaac at home  We read Midsummer Nights dream in evening - 

Tuesday 7 March -

Rainy still,  Isaac at home - no mail on account of weather - mailed a letter home -  Isaac wrote George to come out here saying he would pay travelling expenses - how good & kind -
Completed

Wednesday 8 March

Fine morning - red birds singing sweetly - Everything bright & green after the warm rain - I went to the office and drew two little pictures with crayons - Sewed a little on my talman? - In evening we read Gilfillan's Milton - Last evening we read Taming the Shrew.

Thursday 9 March

Rainy again all day -  Isaac at home in office  Mr. Roots & P.? K. came in eve - with money. I read "Ivanhoe"  made night cap  Mailed letter to Anna

Friday 10 March

Pleasant day  Isaac went to Big Muddy - came home at night announcing the coming of some half dosen? more - Messrs Broad? Kingsbury, Smith & Major -
Completed

Saturday 11 March -

Pleasant - Mr Broad left with Mr Jackson for Chester and returned before night unable to cross Beaucoup - will remain here over Sabbath  Miss Paine and Miss Reynolds here all afternoon - Miss Paine going home during warm weather - Mr Wood called being unable to get to his Sabbath engagement at Carbondale

Sabbath 12 March -

Most delightful day - I went to chh in A.M.  Mr. Bird preached from "It is a vain thing to serve God". Good sermon. Sung with Mr Broad & Mr Smith - In evening when we were busy talking about the sacredness of the day and the duty of observing it in came the Minister & Elder and presently the Elders wife & Miss Paine to spend the Evening!
Completed

Monday 13 March -

 at home - Major and all the rest unclear but just after dinn.. Major came back - I went to office in afternoon - began little short skirt? for Mayo - Jonquils in full & perfect bloom this morning - Some trees covered with leaves  Mr Russel came at night -

Tuesday 14 March

 at home with Mr Russel in office - Mrs Wood & Martha here till after dinner - I intended to go into Miss Reynolds school with Mrs Keyes but she went to ride & did not return in season  I called at George Smiths & at the door at Dr. Wall's but she was gone -  Read Waverly? - Letters came from home & from Moth - M? at Milo -

Wednesday 15 March -

Shepherd's. Called at Mrs -  Very warm - Several showers  Blue bells in bloom - Quails talking all around the house -  left for Centralia & maybe St Louis
Completed

Thursday 16 March

Went to office before breakfast with Mr. W. Reed for P. House Plan - Ran about out doors. Very warm. Mr Major left on foot - burned up his hay yesterday & wished Kingsbury had been in the middle of the bundle!  Letters from Bangor {Lucy}  Three business letters - Vouchers sent by Mitchell came - Even so many papers having had none for nearly three weeks

Friday 17 March -

Put short dress on Mayo - He creeps all about but not very fast Long clothes have bothered him  Abby ironed - I feel tired and have some headaches - Went over to Mrs Clough with shirt - Mrs Keyes carried me in buggy - Called at Mr Johnsons. Mr ?hings and Mr. Roots - Ephriam seems cheerful -  O that he knew our "Best Friend"   Mr Hinckly gone to St Louis  I sent for four or five articles
Completed

{Saturday 18 March}

Not well today - Headache all day - Stove in kitchen fell down with a tremendous creak with a kettle of boiling water and another of sauce stewing - pe?? came very near falling on little Mayo who was ?.d? in his little chair not far away fr. the stove.  I got such a fright that in ten minutes I had high fever

Sabbath 19 March -

Fever again all the afternoon. Sent for Dr. W. at night. He told me to take Quinine as soon as the fever was gone -

Monday - 20 -

Fever did not leave me till nearly morning so I could not take Quinine till five oclock - Took about Eight grains before ten oclock  Had fever again in P.M. - O how I wish Isaac was here
Completed

Sabbath April 16. 1854 -

Am much better - Isaac came from St Louis 23 March - I was then so weak & nervous that meeting him made me tremble all over & I had to ask him not to talk to me  But a kind Providence is restoring to to me health & strength - How thankful sh'd I be -

Saturday April 29 -

Tomorrow will be our last Sabbath here before journeying East if nothing prevents us. Last Monday we all went to Mr Roots, Tuesday to Little Muddy and Richmond - Spent Wed. at R. while Isaac went to Centralia back to Mr Holts Thursday - home Friday morn - Visited at Mr Hinckly in the afternoon of Friday with Mrs Keyes - Finished three dresses for Mayo - Today Mrs Wall sent him a little white sack - Mrs Holt gave me second Mrs Judson's Memoir  We carried "Queechy"? to Mrs Holt & "Voice of Nature" to Mrs Roots - Isaac's very busy tonight at the office - Some days this week cold as Winter  White frost one morning - Rain enough to verde? streams very much
Completed

[on left side]:
And must we then be weaned from Earth -
And taught to seek a Heavenly home -
By sundered ties of blood and birth -
Heart rending partings must they come?
Will not these wandering hearts repent 
Forsake Earth's joys a Heaven to gain
Except the scourging rod be sent
And links be missed from Love's dear chain!

R/  Sulph Morphia  gr 4?

     Semp. Synch      }4
     Mix & Add
      Antimonial Wine }1
    Sps. Nis. dulc.  }1
    Tines? Digitalis  }8s
   Dose  teaspoonful  three times a day

Calcined Magnesia  }4?
Large spoonful occasionally as may be necessary for cathartic
Dear Nettie,

The above is what Dr Merrill recommends for your difficulties.  You can go to a Dr their, or an apothecary's store and get the Dr to mix & prepare the first - & the Magnesia you can manage yourself. If you are well you need not get it - but be?une? you do if you are still
Completed

troubled as when you left. Dr M. said if your feet were cold - if you had some rough woolen stockings sprinkle the inside of them with red pepper. I think it might answer the same purpose, to take a teaspoon full of the pepper & put it into a half teacup of water &  & dab you feet with it with a little rag.
Completed

Dear laborers in the vineyard of the Lord -
Blest teachers to the dark browed Burmat's? sons
How patiently ye suffered cruel deeds of woe!
But now in Heaven how glorious are your crowns!
The souls ye saved like stars are shining there -
Your griefs are oer - your robes are washed and white
Pure as the light in Jesus precious blood -
Methinks I'd love to follow in your steps -
To carry Gospel news to India's shore -
O that I were but worthy thus to toil!
O that this sinful heart loved Jesus more!
Blest Savior! Make me more like thee - Give me
A heart to work wherein thy wisdom points.
Here let me labor zealously for Thee,
With all my might do what my hands shall find -

                                                  M? P. M?  maybe A?P.M.?
Completed

Our warmest sympathies are yours but we know by expense that in a trial like yours words cannot comfort except from the hands that stitched closer? than a troth
A loving heavenly father - a sympathing savior and thoughts of a glorious Heaven where glorious spirits dwell alone? can cheer the heart that mourns a dear one "gone before" - A Sister in Heaven - safe at home!  Is there not joy in the thought! You sorrow indeed that you have lost her sweet society on earth but she loves you now more orderly? unclear

and your affections cling unclear her more fomly? than ever - O be this your one great  th..s? to spend eternity with her  May her ho..? den?  unclear friend be yours forever

This is from home Nettie and I thought you would be gad to see any thing that grew in our home.  Jack Frost bit the Parent but -- I hope he as not killed it.  It was a beautiful plant.  I only had it for past- six weeks.
